t: Song of Solomon 8
If*pn only I could treat you like my brother, one*ln who nursed at my mother’s breasts, I*ln would find you in public and kiss you, and*ln no one would scorn me.
I*ln would lead you, I would take you, to*ln the house of my mother who taught me. I*ln would give you spiced wine to drink from*ln the juice of my pomegranate.
May*ln his left hand be under my head, and*ln his right arm embrace me.
Young*ln women of Jerusalem, I charge you, do*ln not stir up or awaken love until*ln the appropriate time.
Young Women
Who*pn is this coming up from the wilderness, leaning*ln on the one she loves?
Woman
I*pn awakened you under the apricot tree. There*ln your mother conceived you; there*ln she conceived and gave you birth.
Set*ln me as a seal on your heart, as*ln a seal on your arm. For*ln love is as strong as death; jealousy*ln is as unrelenting as Sheol. Love’s*ln flames are fiery flames— an*ln almighty flame!
A*ln huge torrent cannot extinguish love; rivers*ln cannot sweep it away. If*ln a man were to give all his wealth for love, it*ln would be utterly scorned.
Brothers
Our*pn sister is young; she*ln has no breasts. What*ln will we do for our sister on*ln the day she is spoken for?
If*ln she is a wall, we*ln will build a silver barricade on her. If*ln she is a door, we*ln will enclose her with cedar planks.
Woman
I*pn am a wall and*ln my breasts like towers. So*ln to him I have become like*ln one who finds peace.
Solomon*pn owned a vineyard in Baal-hamon. He*ln leased the vineyard to tenants. Each*ln was to bring for his fruit one*ln thousand pieces of silver.
I*ln have my own vineyard. The*ln one thousand are for you, Solomon, but*ln two hundred for those who take care of its fruits.
Man
You*pn who dwell in the gardens, companions*ln are listening for your voice; let*ln me hear you!
Woman
Run*pn away with me, my love, and*ln be like a gazelle or*ln a young stag on*ln the mountains of spices.
